byline.contributor: Karam Shoumali reported from Antakya, Anne Barnard from Beirut, Lebanon, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Hwaida Saad contributed reporting from Beirut, and Mark Mazzetti from Washington.
byline.original: By KARAM SHOUMALI, ANNE BARNARD and ERIC SCHMITT

abstract: Leader of small band of Syrian fighters trained by Pentagon to battle Islamic State there is abducted by rival extremist group Nusra Front along with his deputy and recruit trainer Nadeem Hassan; abductions underscore challenges United States faces as it attempts to assemble local army to battle extremists, effort laden by desertions, stringent screening process and wariness of beginning conflict with government forces under Pres Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: A troubled Pentagon program to train Syrian insurgents to fight the Islamic State has produced only a tiny band of fighters ready to do battle.

headline.main: Abductions Hurt U.S. Bid to Train Anti-ISIS Rebels in Syria
headline.print_headline: Abductions Hurt U.S. Bid to Train Anti-ISIS Rebels

snippet: A troubled Pentagon program to train Syrian insurgents to fight the Islamic State has produced only a tiny band of fighters ready to do battle.
